    implicit none

    integer :: n, s, q, tem, i, ierr

children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read multiple test cases until end of file. ok = .true.

    do

        read(*,*, iostat= ierr) n

        if(ierr <0 ) exit  ! Assuming EOF.

        allocate(a(n), b(n))

        read(*,*) (a(i), i=1,n)

        b =0

        s = -1

        q =0

        tem =1

        do while (q <n )

            s = s +1

            if(tem ==1 ) then

                ! forward loop. do i=1, n

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1

                        q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =0

            else

                ! backward

                do i =n,1, -1

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1

                        q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =1

            end if

        end do

        print*, s

        deallocate( a, b )

    end do

end program codeforces_583_B

Hmm, let's check for necessary parts.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Now, putting it all together with proper Fortran syntax. One thing: in Fortran, when you read a(1:n) with the code above, the line 'read (*, *) (a(i), i=1,n)' reads all elements in sequential order.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Alternatively, we could do 'read (*,*) a' since once allocated to n elements, it can read directly into the array. So 'read(*,*) a' instead of using a loop. That might be simpler.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Yes, better:

After allocate(a(n), b(n)), then:

read(*,*) a

Then all elements read in a(1) to a(n). So replacing that would make the code shorter. Thus the code becomes:

program codeforces_583_B

    implicit none

    integer :: n, s, q, tem, i, ierr

    integer, allocatable :: a(:), b(:)

    do

        read(*,*, iostat= ierr) n

        if(ierr <0 ) exit

        allocate(a(n), b(n))

        read(*,*) a

        b =0

        s = -1

        q =0

        tem =1

        do while (q /= n)

            s = s +1

            if(tem ==1 ) then

                do i=1, n

                    if( a(i) < = q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1; q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =0

            else

                do i =n,1, -1

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1; q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =1

            end if

        end do

        print*, s

        deallocate(a,b)

    end do

end program codeforces_583_B

first element (a(1)=1 <= 0? no. So skip. Second element (a=0 <=0 ? yes: set b to 1, q becomes 1. Thus after first iteration (s=0), q is now 1. Then the next iteration of the do-while loop (since q is not 2 yet).

             do i = n, 1, -1

                   if (a(i) <= q) then

                       if (b(i) ==0 ) then

                           b(i) =1

                           q = q +1

                       end if

                   end if

             end do

             tem =1

         end if

    end do

    print the s.

    deallocate arrays.

End loop.

Wait but the condition in the Java code for the while loop is while (q != n). So in Fortran, the loop is:

do while ( q .ne. n )

Inside, after each direction loop.

Wait the loop structure could have the s increment at the top.

Wait in Java code:

while(q !=n):

   s++;

   if(tem ==1) then process forward.

So that's same as:

initial s is -1. When you enter while loop, first s increments to 0.

The code structure in fortran:

    q =0; s= -1; tem =1;

    do while ( q .ne. n )

        s = s +1

        .. direction loop halves

    end do

Wait the loop condition breaks when q == n.

Yes, so the code structure is correct.

Now, the variables and allocation in Fortran need allocatable arrays, or using arrays with proper dynamic memory.

In Fortran, you can have allocatable arrays. Let me structure the code accordingly.

Starting with the main program:

program codeforces_583_B

    implicit none

    integer :: n, s, q, tem, i, ierr

    integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a, b

    logical ok

    ! Read multiple test cases until end of file.

    ok = .true.

    do

        read(*,*, iostat= ierr) n

        if(ierr <0 ) exit  ! Assuming EOF.

        allocate(a(n), b(n))

        read(*,*) (a(i), i=1,n)

        b =0

        s = -1

        q =0

        tem =1

        do while (q <n )

            s = s +1

            if(tem ==1 ) then

                ! forward loop.

                do i=1, n

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1

                        q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =0

            else

                ! backward

                do i =n,1, -1

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1

                        q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =1

            end if

        end do

        print*, s

        deallocate( a, b )

    end do

end program codeforces_583_B

Hmm, let's check for necessary parts.

Wait, the 'and' operator in Fortran uses the .and. operator for logicals. The condition a(i) <=q and b(i)==0 is correct as written.

Wait in Fortran, to set the entire array b to 0, the line 'b=0' works because it is an allocatable array of integers.

But we have to make sure that after allocation, the array is initialized to zero.

Alternatively, using a loop to set each element to zero, but array assignment is better.

Yes, b=0 is fine.

The loop over the test cases uses read with iostat to detect end-of-file. The code reads n, and if that read is EOF (iostat error, but negative) then exit.

Wait, in the initial read for n: if there's input available, it will read, else the EOF error will have ierr <0. The loop then will terminate. Otherwise continue.

The reads for a's array need to read n integers into a. Then processing.

The code after processing will print s once per test case.

I think this should be the correct code. Need to test for any off-by-one errors since indices in Fortran are 1-based.

In Java, arrays were 0-based, so the loops in Java were from i=0 to n-1. In Fortran, it's from 1 to n, so the indices line up.

Thus, the code should handle that.

Let me see edge cases. Suppose n=1.

Then q starts as 0. The first iteration:

s becomes 0. Since tem is 1 (first time), loop forward.

i=1, check a(1) <=0.

Assuming a(1)=0: then set to 1, q becomes 1, so loop exits, s=0, correct.

Wait in the code, if the a is [0], then:

First, in first pass (tem=1, s increments from -1 to 0). Within forward loop, a(1)=0 <= q (0), so set b=1, q becomes 1. So after first iteration, q equals n=1, so loop ends.

Thus S is 0, correct.

Another test case: when n=2 and the a array is [1,0].

So first pass: tem is 1 (forward direction):

Check each:

first element (a(1)=1 <= 0? no. So skip.

Second element (a=0 <=0 ? yes: set b to 1, q becomes 1.

Thus after first iteration (s=0), q is now 1. Then the next iteration of the do-while loop (since q is not 2 yet).

Next, s increments to 1. tem was set to 0 (after first loop was forward direction, so tem is now 0. So the next iteration is backward loop.

Loop from i=2 down to 1.

First i=2: already processed (b=1), so skip.

i=1: a(1) is 1 <=1 (current q is 1). So check, b is 0. So mark it, q becomes 2.

Then after the backward loop's processing, q becomes 2, so the do-while loop ends.

Thus s =1. Which would be the correct result.

The code's S after two cycles (from s=0 and up to s=1) is correct.

Thus seems the code works. The variables are correctly initialized, and logic follows.

Now, putting it all together with proper Fortran syntax.

One thing: in Fortran, when you read a(1:n) with the code above, the line 'read (*, *) (a(i), i=1,n)' reads all elements in sequential order.

Alternatively, we could do 'read (*,*) a' since once allocated to n elements, it can read directly into the array. So 'read(*,*) a' instead of using a loop. That might be simpler.

Yes, better:

After allocate(a(n), b(n)), then:

read(*,*) a

Then all elements read in a(1) to a(n).

So replacing that would make the code shorter.

Thus the code becomes:

program codeforces_583_B

    implicit none

    integer :: n, s, q, tem, i, ierr

    integer, allocatable :: a(:), b(:)

    do

        read(*,*, iostat= ierr) n

        if(ierr <0 ) exit

        allocate(a(n), b(n))

        read(*,*) a

        b =0

        s = -1

        q =0

        tem =1

        do while (q /= n)

            s = s +1

            if(tem ==1 ) then

                do i=1, n

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1; q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =0

            else

                do i =n,1, -1

                    if( a(i) <= q .and. b(i)==0 ) then

                        b(i)=1; q = q +1

                    end if

                end do

                tem =1

            end if

        end do

        print*, s

        deallocate(a,b)

    end do

end program codeforces_583_B

This should be a correct translation.
